questions.text: Identify the organism from the given image? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospira

 

The organisms in the image are leptospira.

 

In spirochetes, the presence of two axial filaments (periplasmic flagella) with polar insertions are located in periplasmic space called as endoflagella, which are responsible for the characteristic corkscrew motion of these bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Vibrio species are comma-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, commonly known for causing cholera (Vibrio cholerae).

 

Option C. Helicobacter: Helicobacter pylori are spiral-shaped bacteria known for causing stomach ulcers and are Gram-negative.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Salmonella species are rod-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, known for causing foodborne illnesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospira is identified by its spiral morphology with axial filaments (endoflagella) and is a type of spirochete, along with Treponema and Borrelia.

 

Endoflagella are seen in:

 

  • Treponema
  • Borrelia
  • Leptospira

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl's eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

Owl's eye appearance on urinary examination is typically seen in Cytomegalovirus.

 

CMV, Human Herpes Virus 5, Largest virus in Herpesviridae family

 

 

 

Other options are not associated with Owl’s eye appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl's eye" appearance of cells in the urine is a diagnostic clue for Cytomegalovirus infection, especially relevant for diagnosing congenital CMV infections in neonates or severe infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with history of fever and enlarged lymph nodes and sore throat was suspected to have infectious mono-nucleosis and was ordered a Paul Bunnel test. Which of the following is the principle of the test? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibody test

 

  • Paul Bunnell test is a heterophile antibody reaction test and is used in glandular fever like Infectious mononucleosis.
  • Heterophile antibodies have the ability to agglutinate RBCs of different animal species.
  • Paul Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes for agglutination and Monospot test uses horse erythrocytes for agglutination.
  • In Infectious Mononucleosis, IgM heterophile antibodies are detectable for the first 3 months of infection and they can agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Complement mediated cell damage: This refers to a different mechanism where the complement system causes lysis of cells. It is not related to the principle of the Paul Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Precipitation reaction uses a soluble antigen to form a precipitate in a solid media when combined with an antibody.

 

Option D. Neutralisation reaction: Neutralization reactions involve antibodies that neutralize the pathogen, preventing it from infecting cells. This principle does not apply to the Paul Bunnell test.

 

Educational Objective

 

The Paul Bunnell test is a heterophile antibody test used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis. It detects IgM heterophile antibodies that can agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, which are present during the early stages of the infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talaromyces marneffei

 

The most likely causative organism based on the history and image given is Talaromyces marneffei (Penicillium marneffei).

 

T. marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. It is diagnosed by blood culture, which shows a mold with a powdery surface and characteristic red pigment that diffuses into the agar. Histopathological examination reveals yeast-like organisms with central septation.

 

Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.

 

Mild and moderate infections can be treated with itraconazole. Amphotericin B is recommended for severe infections.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces are thermally dimorphic fungi and cause blastomycosis. Primary infection usually affects the lungs, which can later disseminate through the blood to form multiple abscesses at sites such as skin and bone. Culture at 25-30 degrees Celsius promotes hyphal growth. Microscopic examination of stained specimens shows broad-based budding yeast cells.

 

Option C. Aspergillus colonies have a velvety powdery surface, of which the color varies according to the species. Aspergillus fumigatus is seen as dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black colored. Yellow-green growth is seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. On microscopy, dichotomous branching at acute angles seen after staining is characteristic. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients.

 

The image below shows Aspergillus niger colonies.

 

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii cannot be cultured. On being stained by methenamine silver, the cyst wall appears black under the microscope. Trophozoites can also be seen after staining. Clinical features include dyspnea, fever, and cough. It can cause lethal pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. Diffuse bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates can be seen on chest radiograph.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Recognition of the red diffusible pigment in culture is critical in identifying Talaromyces marneffei infection, particularly in HIV-positive patients. It's important to consider this pathogen when patients from endemic regions present with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves antifungal therapy tailored to the severity of the infection, with agents such as itraconazole for mild cases and amphotericin B for severe cases.

questions.text: Identify the bacterium observed in the provided Gram-stained specimen? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d. Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Explanation:


 The specimen displays pink-colored paired cocci indicative of a Gram-negative diplococci, characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This organism is known for its distinct kidney bean-shaped morphology and its tendency to appear in pairs (diplococci), fitting the description observed in the Gram stain.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Incorrect as this organism typically appears as lanceolate (pointed) shaped Gram-positive cocci in pairs and is not Gram-negative.
 

Option B. Hemophilus influenzae: Incorrect because it generally presents as Gram-negative bacilli or coccobacilli, not as diplococci.


Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Incorrect as it is a Gram-positive cocci that forms clusters resembling grapes, not the paired structure typical of gonococci.

 

Educational Objective:


Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococci that is distinct for its kidney bean shape and pairs arrangement, often found within neutrophils on microscopic examination.

questions.text: The test shown in the image below. Which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

The given image shows blood agar culture with bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin.

 

Among the options given, Streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is catalase-positive and does not typically exhibit bacitracin sensitivity. It is identified by coagulase testing and its ability to grow in the presence of high salt concentrations.

 

Option C. Clostridium botulinum: Clostridium botulinum is an anaerobic Gram-positive rod and is not identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Option D. Bacillus: Bacillus species are Gram-positive rods that form spores and are not typically identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Educational Objective

 

The bacitracin disk test is used to identify Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which is characterized by its sensitivity to bacitracin and beta-hemolytic activity on blood agar. This test differentiates S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, which are resistant to bacitracin.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia

 

Explanation:

 

Orientia, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is transmitted by chigger mites, not by the tick shown in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia: Transmitted by ticks

 

Option C. Ehrlichia: Also transmitted by ticks

 

Option D. Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever : Also transmitted by ticks

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, responsible for scrub typhus, is not transmitted by ticks but by chigger mites, distinguishing it from other tick-borne infections like Babesia and Ehrlichia.

choices.text: Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic
That the patient is in window period

questions.text: The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV2 in the blood likely indicates? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV 2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection even if the patient has been asymptomatic.

 

1-3 weeks after symptoms onset, SARS CoV2 antibody become detectable. At this time infectiousness is decreased and some amount of immunity from future infection has developed.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Presence of acute viral load: The presence of antibodies does not indicate an acute viral load. Acute infection is usually detected through the presence of viral RNA using PCR tests, not antibodies.

 

Option C. A high risk of reinfection: The presence of antibodies suggests that the individual has some level of immunity, which generally reduces the risk of reinfection rather than increasing it.

 

Option D. That the patient is in window period: The window period refers to the time after initial infection when antibodies are not yet detectable. Therefore, the presence of antibodies indicates that the patient is beyond the window period.

 

Educational objective

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection, which may have been asymptomatic. This serological evidence shows that the person has developed an immune response to the virus.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with multiple abscesses over his face, chest, and back. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, he has atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgE syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of the boy with recurrent skin and respiratory infections, atopic excoriating skin, and notably, cold abscesses, strongly points towards Hyper IgE syndrome, also known as Job's syndrome. This condition is characterized by:

 

  • High levels of IgE: Elevated IgE is a hallmark of the syndrome and contributes to the immune dysregulation seen in these patients.
  • Recurrent infections: Due to defects in immune regulation, particularly affecting the response of neutrophils and other immune cells.
  • Dermatologic issues: Such as eczema and atopic dermatitis are common and often severe in these patients.
  • Genetic background: Hyper IgE syndrome is commonly caused by mutations in the STAT3 gene, which is critical for many aspects of immune system function, including the development and function of neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgM syndrome: Incorrect, characterized by elevated levels of IgM with low levels of other immunoglobulins, leading to a susceptibility to infections. It does not typically present with high IgE levels or eczema.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Incorrect, this is a condition that affects blood cells and immune response, characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections; however, it does not typically involve high levels of IgE or cold abscesses.

 

Option D. Carcinoid syndrome: Incorrect, typically presents with symptoms caused by secreted hormones, such as flushing, diarrhea, and heart valve problems, which are unrelated to the immune dysfunction seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgE syndrome should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of high IgE levels, recurrent skin and respiratory infections, and dermatologic issues such as eczema. Managing this condition often involves addressing the skin care comprehensively and preventing infections through vigilant monitoring and appropriate use of antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureaplasma urealyticum

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall.

 

They vary in form, although most have sterols that make the cell membrane somewhat more rigid.

 

Many are able to move about through gliding, but members of the genus Spiroplasma are helical and move by twisting.

 

The best-known genus in the Mollicutes is Mycoplasma. Colonies show the typical “fried-egg” appearance.

 

Mollicutes are parasites of various animals and plants, living on or in the host’s cells. Many cause diseases in humans, attaching to cells in the respiratory or urogenital tracts, particularly species of Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma. Phytoplasma and Spiroplasma are plant pathogens associated with insect vectors.

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum has the ability to hydrolyse urea. It causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Orientia tsutsugamushi: This bacterium belongs to the family Rickettsiaceae and is the causative agent of scrub typhus, which is transmitted by mites.

 

Option C. Chlamydophila pneumonia: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydophila, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydia, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes various infections, including trachoma and sexually transmitted infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma, with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: Which method of diagnosis is shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Darkfield microscopy

 

The given image is of darkfield microscopy as it has a dark background with a refractile organism.

 

Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present. This technique allows for a presumptive diagnosis of syphilis even before antibodies have developed.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Phase contrast microscopy:

 

  • Phase contrast microscopy enhances the contrast of transparent specimens without staining. It is often used for live cells and other transparent samples.
  • The background in phase contrast microscopy is not typically as dark as in darkfield microscopy.

 

Option C. Fluorescent microscopy

 

  • Fluorescent microscopy uses fluorophores to stain specific structures, which then emit light when exposed to specific wavelengths. The images typically show bright fluorescent colors against a dark background.

 

Option D. Electron microscopy

 

  • Electron microscopy uses a beam of electrons to create an image. The images produced are typically in black and white with extremely high resolution, showing detailed structures at the nanoscale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Darkfield microscopy is identified by its characteristic bright specimen against a dark background and is commonly used for diagnosing syphilis through visualization of spirochetes.

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause neurological disease and death in people. WNV is commonly found in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, North America and West Asia. In Mumbai in the year 1952, the antibodies against WNV were first detected in humans. Since then, the virus activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India. WNV is maintained in nature in a cycle involving transmission between birds and mosquitoes. Humans, horses and other mammals can be infected.

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.

 

West Nile virus can be diagnosed by a number of different tests:

 

  • IgG antibody sero-conversion (or significant increase in antibody titers) in two serial specimen collected at a one week interval by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • IgM antibody capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • neutralisation assays;
  • viral detection by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, and
  • virus isolation by cell culture.

 

IgM can be detected in nearly all cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum specimens received from WNV infected patients at the time of their clinical presentation. Serum IgM antibody may persist for more than a year.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Hendra virus is endemic to Australia

 

Option C: Ebola virus is endemic to Africa.

 

Option D: Yellow fever endemic to South and Central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Strongyloidiasis:

 

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

 

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.

 

The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

 

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ﻿﻿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ﻿﻿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B. Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends.

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh coloured when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: This nematode causes strongyloidiasis and is much smaller and thread-like in appearance compared to Ascaris lumbricoides.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, this parasite is much smaller and thinner than Ascaris lumbricoides and is primarily found in the colon and rectum.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is a hookworm that has a different morphology with a characteristic curved anterior end, and it primarily inhabits the small intestine where it attaches to the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine, identifiable by its large size, cylindrical shape with tapered ends, and characteristic mouth with three finely toothed lips.

choices.text: They are sequestered in the spleen.
They adhere to the capillary endothelium and are not circulating in peripheral blood.
They are removed due to antigen-antibody reactions.
They are only present in the mosquito vector's bloodstream.

questions.text: Why are schizonts and late trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum typically absent in peripheral blood smears? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. They adhere to the capillary endothelium and are not circulating in peripheral blood.

 

Explanation:

 

Plasmodium falciparum is unique among malaria parasites due to its ability to cytoadhere to the endothelial lining of capillaries and venules. This sequestration of mature parasites (schizonts and late trophozoites) is mediated by parasite proteins such as PfEMP1, which bind to specific receptors on endothelial cells by sequestering in deep tissues, P. falciparum avoids splenic clearance, a major host defense mechanism, contributing to the pathogenesis of severe malaria. This is why these mature stages are not typically found in peripheral blood smears.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. They are sequestered in the spleen: While the spleen plays a role in filtering infected red blood cells, the primary reason for the absence of mature P. falciparum in peripheral blood is cytoadherence, not splenic sequestration.
  • Option c. They are removed due to antigen-antibody reactions: Immune clearance plays a role in controlling malaria infection, but it is not the primary reason for the absence of mature parasites in the peripheral blood.
  • Option d. They are only present in the mosquito vector's bloodstream: Mature P. falciparum develop within human red blood cells and are sequestered in human tissues, not the mosquito's bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The absence of schizonts and late trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum in peripheral blood smears is due to their adherence to capillary endothelial, a crucial factor in the pathogenesis of severe malaria.

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a Xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

 

Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient is the Xeno diagnostic method among the given options.

 

Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.

 

Uses -

 

  1. Chagas disease diagnosis. Reduviid bugs (vector/foreign host) grown in laboratories are permitted to feed on suspicious patients (original host). The feces of the bugs are checked under a microscope for amastigote forms of the pathogen Trypanosoma cruzi after 4-5 weeks.
  2. Identification of dengue virus – viruses are inoculated into the mosquitoes . The virus can be demonstrated easily as it multiplies in different organs of the mosquito (Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus, and Toxorhynchites) and can be easily demonstrated.
  3. In Trichinella spirals infection, Laboratory rats are used as a T. spiralis vector by feeding them pieces of muscle biopsies from suspected patients. The infected lab rats' muscles can be seen to contain T. spiralis larvae.

 

Advantage of xenodiagnosis: helpful in cases where low pathogen count makes direct microscopic diagnosis DIFFICULT.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli: Incorrect: This is not a xenodiagnostic method. It involves testing the virulence of enterotoxigenic E. coli by observing the fluid accumulation in ligated sections of rabbit intestine.

 

Option C. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: Incorrect: This method involves animal inoculation rather than using a vector to diagnose an infection.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: Incorrect: This is a virulence testing method to determine the presence of toxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to ingest potentially infected tissue or fluids and then examining the vector for the presence of the pathogen, making it particularly useful in cases where direct detection of the pathogen is challenging due to low numbers.

questions.text: The toxin produced by the organisms shown below acts via? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ADP ribosylation of EF2

 

The given image shows gram-positive rods with club-shaped ends, beaded appearance, and a Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement indicative of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

 

Diphtheria toxin functions by selectively ADP-ribosylating ribosomal elongation factor, EF-2, attenuating protein synthesis and leading to cell death within a matter of hours. DT is a highly potent toxin. It is bacteriophage mediated.

 

NOTE: Pseudomonas toxin also inhibits protein synthesis by ADP ribosylation of EF2.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increase in cAMP: This mechanism is typically associated with toxins such as cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, which lead to an increase in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) by ADP-ribosylating G proteins, but not involved in the action of diphtheria toxin.

 

Option B. Increase in cGMP: This mechanism is not relevant to diphtheria toxin but is associated with certain bacterial toxins like heat-stable enterotoxin (ST) produced by E. coli, which increases cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels.

 

Option D. RNA glycosidase: This mechanism refers to Shiga toxin and ricin, which inhibit protein synthesis by enzymatically removing adenine from rRNA, but it is not the mode of action for diphtheria toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin acts by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), thereby inhibiting protein synthesis and leading to cell death.

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis with a history of fever for 4 days and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel and tick bite. His CSF findings showed increased protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely organism to cause this clinical picture? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings are suggestive of viral meningitis, most probably caused by an Enterovirus. Enteroviruses are common causes of viral meningitis and present with fever, rashes, and mild lymphocytosis in the CSF.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. West Nile virus: Although it can cause meningitis, there is no history of travel, making this less likely. West Nile virus is endemic in certain regions of North America like California Central Valley, southwestern Arizona, southern Texas, and Louisiana, which have both compatible climates and avian reservoirs for the disease.

 

Option B. Meningococci: Typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Option C. Strep pneumoniae: Also typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Educational objective

 

CSF Findings for Different Types of Meningitis:

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

 

The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

 

  • Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.
  • The commonly implemented methods for identifying Candida are 10% potassium hydroxide stain and culture with sabouraud dextrose agar. Differentiation of specific species is possible with special culture mediums like CHROMagar Candida. 
  • ELISA and PCR tests are used in cases of invasive candidiasis and to differentiate Candida dubliniensis from Candida albicans.
  • It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.
  • It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

 

Option C. Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

 

Option D. Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudo membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

questions.text: A patient recovered from Covid-19, treated with steroids, now presents with nasal discharge for 3 weeks. What does the histopathological image indicate? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucor species, suggesting a diagnosis of mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically shows septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Candida: Forms yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae.

 

Option D. Trichosporon: Forms hyaline hyphae and arthroconidia, different from what is seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is the cause of fungal infections characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those recently treated with steroids post-Covid-19 infection.

choices.text: Real-time PCR to detect viral mRNA
Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.text: SARS-Cov-2 can be detected by all except? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Southern blotting

 

Southern Blotting: This technique is used for the detection of specific DNA sequences in DNA samples. This is not applicable for detecting SARS-CoV-2 because the virus is RNA-based and there is not enough DNA in the collected samples to obtain a pattern on gel electrophoresis. RNA viruses require different techniques such as RT-PCR for detection.

 

Other Options

 

Tests for SARS CoV2

 

  • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR):

  • Method: This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.

  • Explanation: It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.

  • Rapid Antigen Test:

  • Method: This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.

  • Explanation: It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.

  • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay):

  • Method: This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.

  • Explanation: It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.

 

Educational Objective

 

Southern blotting is not a suitable method for detecting SARS-CoV-2 as it is designed to detect DNA, while SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus and requires RNA-specific detection techniques.

choices.text: Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India
Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax
Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria
Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax

 

  • The absence, not the presence, of the Duffy blood group antigen, is protective against P. vivax because the Duffy antigen normally serves as the receptor for Plasmodium vivax.
  • Drug Efflux pumps are the primary mode of resistance for Chloroquine. It is mediated by an ABC transporter encoded by P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1).
  • Algid malaria is a rare complication of severe malaria characterized by hemodynamic collapse manifesting as shock with pronounced metabolic changes and hypothermia.
  • Relapse is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale.
  • Malaria relapse:
    • True relapse is caused due to Hypnozoites.
    • These are resting forms.
  • In the case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which:
    • multiply inside hepatic cells to form - Schizonts
    • others persist and remain dormant as - hypnozoites
  • From time to time some are activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.
  • In the case of Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium malaria, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence technically relapse is not seen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India: This statement is correct. Drug-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum are a significant concern in India.

 

Option C. Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria: This statement is correct. Algid malaria is a rare but severe complication of malaria characterized by shock and metabolic disturbances.

 

Option D. Relapse is seen in P. ovale: This statement is correct. Relapse is seen in Plasmodium ovale as well as Plasmodium vivax due to the presence of hypnozoites.

 

Educational Objective

 

The absence of the Duffy blood group antigen is protective against Plasmodium vivax, not its presence.

questions.text: Dr. Verma is examining the criteria used to establish the Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA) for nutrients and focuses on the typical characteristics of a "reference woman". Which of the following correctly describes this reference woman used for RDA calculations? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Weight 55 kgs

 

  • Weight of 55 kgs: This is used as a standard measurement in RDA calculations to reflect an average baseline for determining nutrient needs in adult women.
  • It represents a balance that is thought to be typical or ideal for maintaining health without excessive caloric intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reference woman used in the calculation of recommended daily allowance (RDA)

 

  • Aged between 19-39 years
  • Non pregnant, non-lactating
  • Weight=55kgs
  • Height = 1.61 m
  • BMI=21.2
  • Free from disease and physically fit for active work
  • Engaged in moderate activity for 8 hours on each working day
  • Spends 8 hours in bed, 4-6 hours in sitting and moving, 2hours in walking and in active recreation or household activities.

choices.text: Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) - Promotes increased fluid loss via enterotoxins
Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) - Prevents fluid absorption by aggregative adherence
Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) - Invades and destroys colonic epithelial cells
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) - Produces Shiga toxin inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of severe abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea after eating undercooked beef at a family barbecue. The child's condition raises concern for a specific E. coli infection associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome. The physician aims to identify the correct strain of E. coli so to plan the treatment protocol based on the pathogenic mechanism of strain. Match the E. coli strain with its corresponding pathogenic mechanism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) - Produces Shiga toxin inhibiting protein synthesis

 

Explanation:

 

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces a potent Shiga toxin that inhibits protein synthesis within colonic epithelial cells, leading to cell damage, inflammation, and severe symptoms such as bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramping. EHEC is commonly transmitted through undercooked meats and contaminated foods and can result in serious complications like hemolytic uremic syndrome, particularly in children. Early recognition and management are essential to prevent severe outcomes.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) - Promotes increased fluid loss via enterotoxins: ETEC is a common cause of traveler’s diarrhea, characterized by watery stools without blood. It produces enterotoxins that increase cyclic AMP or GMP, leading to fluid and electrolyte loss in the small intestine, unlike the bloody diarrhea seen in EHEC infections.

 

Option B. Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) - Prevents fluid absorption by aggregative adherence: EAEC adheres to the intestinal mucosa in an aggregative pattern, leading to persistent diarrhea, especially in children. It does not produce Shiga toxin or cause hemorrhagic colitis.

 

Option C. Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) - Invades and destroys colonic epithelial cells: EIEC causes dysentery-like symptoms by invading and destroying the epithelial cells of the large intestine, resulting in fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, but it lacks the Shiga toxin mechanism seen in EHEC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces Shiga toxin, leading to inhibition of protein synthesis and damage to colonic cells, causing bloody diarrhea and the risk of hemolytic uremic syndrome. Understanding the pathogenic mechanisms of different E. coli strains is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of gastrointestinal infections.

questions.text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 37 degrees C

 

Frostbite should be managed with rapid and complete thawing using a circulating water bath maintained between 37°C and 40°C. This temperature range is optimal to reverse vascular stasis and initiate reperfusion without causing thermal injury.

 

Thawing at this range is typically performed for 30 to 60 minutes and should be done only when the possibility of refreezing is excluded. Higher temperatures like 42°C are not recommended and may worsen tissue injury.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 42°C: Too hot. It exceeds the upper recommended limit and can risk thermal damage to already compromised tissue.

 

Option C. 32°C: Insufficient to produce effective rewarming. Rewarming would be slow and incomplete.

 

Option D. 30°C: Ineffective. Tissue remains partially frozen and vulnerable to re-freezing injury.

 

Educational Objective:


Frostbite should be rewarmed in circulating water at 37–40°C for 30–60 minutes, avoiding hot air or dry heat.

questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha actinin

 

The image shows a sarcomere and the arrow marks the Z line which is constituted by Alpha actinin.

 

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins that produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.

 

 

  • Each muscle fiber contains several hundred to several thousand myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril is composed of about 1500 adjacent myosin filaments and 3000 actin filaments.
  • The thick filaments are myosin, and the thin filaments are actin
  • The myosin and actin filaments partially interdigitate and thus cause the myofibrils to have alternate light and dark bands.
  • The light bands contain only actin filaments and are called I bands because they are isotropic to polarized light.
  • The dark bands contain myosin filaments, as well as the ends of the actin filaments where they overlap the myosin, and are called A bands because they are anisotropic to polarized light.
  • Small projections from the sides of the myosin filaments are cross-bridges. The interaction between these cross-bridges and the actin filaments that causes contraction.
  • The ends of the actin filaments are attached to a so-called Z disc. From this disc, these filaments extend in both directions to interdigitate with the myosin filaments.
  • The Z disc is composed of filamentous proteins different from the actin and myosin filaments, passes
  • crosswise across the myofibril and also crosswise from myofibril to myofibril, attaching the myofibrils to one another all the way across the muscle fiber. Therefore, the entire muscle fiber has light and dark bands, as do the individual myofibrils giving the skeletal and cardiac muscle their striated appearance.
  • The portion of the myofibril (or of the whole muscle fibre) that lies between two successive Z discs is called a sarcomere.

 

Note: Some sources say that even titin is a component of Z-disc so if alpha actinin is not given in the options titin is the second-best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: A thin filament protein that interacts with myosin for muscle contraction but is not specific to the Z line.

 

Option C. Titin: A large elastic protein that spans from the Z line to the M line, providing elasticity and stabilizing the sarcomere's structure. Although titin is associated with the Z line, alpha actinin is the primary constituent.

 

Option D. Tropomyosin: A protein that lies along the actin filament and regulates muscle contraction by controlling access to the myosin-binding sites on actin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Z line in a sarcomere is primarily constituted by alpha actinin, which plays a critical role in anchoring actin filaments and maintaining the structural integrity of the muscle fiber.

questions.text: A young man underwent a surgery on his chest after a trauma an year ago and has developed a lesion as shown. Which of the following is a probable diagnosis in the patient? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keloid

 

The image and clinical history are indicative of a keloid, which is a type of raised scar that grows excessively and extends beyond the original wound boundaries.

 

Keloid:

 

  • Definition: Keloids are overgrowths of scar tissue that develop around a wound, usually after the wound has healed. They are benign and result from an overproduction of collagen.
  • Appearance: Keloids are raised, thick, and can be pink, red, or dark in color. They often grow larger than the original wound and do not regress over time.
  • Location: Commonly occur on the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks but can appear anywhere on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign tumors made up of blood vessels. They usually appear as red or purple marks and are often present at birth or develop shortly after.

 

Option C. Normal scar: A normal scar typically lies flat against the skin and does not extend beyond the boundary of the original wound. It is usually lighter in color compared to keloids.

 

Option D. Hamartoma: Hamartomas are benign, focal malformations that resemble neoplastic tissue but grow at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. They do not typically present as raised scars.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloids are characterized by an excessive overgrowth of scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound, often appearing thick and raised. They are more common in areas such as the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks. The clinical image and description provided align with the diagnosis of a keloid.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs decreases the serum parathyroid hormone levels? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitriol

 

Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D and plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphate metabolism in the body. It directly acts on vitamin D receptors (VDRs) present in the parathyroid gland, leading to a decrease in the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

 

Mechanism of Action: Calcitriol increases the absorption of calcium and phosphate from the intestines. Elevated levels of calcium in the blood provide negative feedback to the parathyroid glands, which reduces the production of PTH. Additionally, calcitriol directly inhibits the synthesis and secretion of PTH by binding to VDRs in the parathyroid gland. This dual action ensures a reduction in PTH levels, making calcitriol an effective treatment for conditions associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Note - Paricalcitol: A synthetic vitamin D receptor (VDR) agonist used to reduce PTH levels in primary hyperparathyroidism. This drug is related to the Cinacalcet, a calcium sensitizer but this act on the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risedronate: Risedronate is a bisphosphonate used to treat osteoporosis. It works by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, which can sometimes lead to hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia can reflexively increase PTH levels, rather than decrease them.

 

Option C. Lithium: Lithium is known to cause unexplained hyperparathyroidism and consequently increase PTH levels. It is one of the common causes of unexplained hyperparathyroidism, making it an unsuitable option for decreasing PTH levels.

 

Option D. Diuretics: Diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, can cause hypocalcemia, which in turn can lead to an increase in PTH levels. Thiazide diuretics can cause hypercalcemia, which might decrease PTH levels, but in this question, "diuretics" is mentioned generally, and loop diuretics are more commonly associated with increased PTH levels due to hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, decreases serum parathyroid hormone levels by increasing calcium absorption from the intestines and directly inhibiting PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands through its action on vitamin D receptors.

choices.text: Necrotizing TB granuloma
Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia
Severe fungal pneumonia

questions.text: A 35-year-old depressed man came with complaints of sudden onset breathlessness, with desaturation. Chest x-ray showed bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominant involvement of right middle and lower lobes. The patient could not be revived despite treatment. On autopsy, the lungs, appeared grossly normal. The histopathology image of the lung is as shown below. Which among the following is the appropriate cause? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia

 

The above image shows a foreign body granuloma. Foreign bodies are surrounded by macrophages and lymphocytes. This change results from aspiration of stomach contents or food particles in this case probably vegetative matter.

 

Aspiration pneumonia occurs in markedly debilitated patients or those who aspirate gastric contents either while unconscious (e.g., after a stroke) or during repeated vomiting. These patients have abnormal gag and swallowing reflexes that predispose to aspiration. The resultant pneumonia is partly chemical because of the extremely irritating effects of the gastric acid, and partly bacterial (from the oral flora). Typically, more than one organism is recovered on culture, aerobes being more common than anaerobes. This type of pneumonia is often necrotizing, pursues a fulminant clinical course, and is a frequent cause of death.

 

The most commonly affected lobes in Necrotizing pneumonia are the right middle and lower lobes, consistent with the findings in this case.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Necrotizing TB granuloma: Tuberculosis typically presents with caseating granulomas, not foreign body granulomas as seen in this image. The clinical scenario also does not support TB.

 

Option C. Sarcoid granuloma: Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, which differ from the foreign body granuloma seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. Severe fungal pneumonia: Fungal infections can cause granulomatous inflammation, but they typically present with necrotizing granulomas or other distinct histological features. The presence of foreign material is more indicative of aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia can lead to the formation of foreign body granulomas, characterized by macrophages and lymphocytes surrounding the aspirated material. This condition is often associated with severe clinical outcomes, especially in debilitated patients.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No 1344

choices.text: Nothing, since CT was normal
Start on aspirin + clopidogrel
Advice BP control

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT shows dense MCA sign. What would be your next step? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous thrombolysis

 

The patient's presentation of acute left-sided facial paralysis and weakness, alongside the finding of a dense MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) sign on a CT scan, indicates an acute ischemic stroke. The dense MCA sign is a radiologic indicator of a thrombus or embolus in the MCA, which is one of the most common sites for cerebral infarctions.

 

Given that the symptoms began only 1 hour ago and the CT has confirmed the location of the occlusion without showing any signs of hemorrhage or extensive infarction (which would contraindicate thrombolysis), intravenous thrombolysis is the most appropriate intervention. This treatment is aimed at dissolving the clot and restoring blood flow to the affected area of the brain.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nothing, since CT was normal: Incorrect because the CT was not normal; it showed a dense MCA sign, indicating an acute stroke.

 

Option B. Start on aspirin + clopidogrel: This would generally be considered in secondary prevention after the acute management phase of ischemic stroke, or if the patient was not a candidate for thrombolysis.

 

Option D. Advice BP control: While controlling blood pressure is important, it is not the immediate next step in the management of a patient showing signs of acute ischemic stroke with a window for thrombolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute ischemic stroke with clear indications, intravenous thrombolysis should be administered as soon as possible within the therapeutic window to improve outcomes. Immediate evaluation and management are critical to maximize recovery and minimize long-term disability.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male farmworker presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent abdominal pain, cramping, and episodes of diarrhea, sometimes with mucus and blood, over the past month. He mentions working closely with pigs and occasionally drinking untreated water from the farm. On examination, he appears dehydrated, but there are no signs of jaundice or organomegaly. Stool microscopy was performed, and the image of an organism found is shown below. Which organism is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Balantidium coli

 

Explanation:

 

The image reveals Balantidium coli, the largest ciliated protozoan parasite that affects humans. This organism typically presents as an oval trophozoite covered with cilia, aiding in its motility within the large intestine. It is characterized by a macronucleus and a micronucleus, and its anterior end has a cytostome, while the posterior end contains a cytopyge. Balantidium coli is transmitted through the fecal-oral route, often linked to exposure to contaminated water or close contact with pigs, which serve as reservoirs. Clinical manifestations include persistent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and occasionally dysentery-like symptoms, aligning with the patient's history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica causes amebiasis with symptoms of dysentery, abdominal pain, and sometimes liver abscesses. Its trophozoites lack cilia and typically display a "bull’s-eye" nucleus, making it morphologically distinct from Balantidium coli.

 

Option C. Giardia lamblia: Giardia lamblia, associated with giardiasis, presents with greasy, malodorous stools and bloating rather than bloody diarrhea. Its trophozoites are pear-shaped with flagella and a characteristic "face-like" appearance, not matching the ciliated structure seen in the image.

 

Option D. Cryptosporidium parvum: Cryptosporidium parvum is known for causing self-limiting watery diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised hosts. Its oocysts are much smaller, round, and non-ciliated, differentiating it from Balantidium coli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Balantidium coli is a ciliated protozoan that can cause gastrointestinal illness, particularly in individuals exposed to contaminated water or in close contact with pigs. It is identified microscopically by its oval shape, cilia, and dual nuclei within the trophozoite form, distinct from other intestinal protozoa. Early identification and appropriate antimicrobial therapy are essential for effective management.

questions.text: Match the following cancers with their respective genes involved: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

 

1. KIT (D): Commonly mutated in Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs), where it plays a critical role in tumor growth and survival.

 

2. K-RAS (C): Frequently mutated in pancreatic cancers, contributing to the cancerous cells’ growth and division.

 

3. JAK 2 (A): Mutations in JAK 2 are associated with various types of myeloproliferative neoplasms, affecting blood cell production.

 

4. ALK (B): ALK gene rearrangements are a key driver in a subset of non-small cell lung cancers, particularly adenocarcinoma, leading to targeted treatment approaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adenocarcinoma lung: Associated with mutations or rearrangements in ALK, making ALK inhibitors a treatment option.
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasm: JAK 2 mutations enhance the understanding and treatment of these diseases.
  • Pancreatic Carcinoma: Known for K-RAS mutations which are pivotal in the development and progression of pancreatic cancer.

choices.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot
Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.text: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest to her to relieve the pain? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

 

Explanation:

 

To relieve leg cramps, the recommended technique is to:

 

  • Extend the knee: Straightening the leg helps in relieving tension and alleviating the cramp.
  • Dorsiflex the foot: This involves pulling the toes towards the shin, which stretches the calf muscles and helps in reducing the cramp.

 

Leg cramps during pregnancy are commonly caused by factors such as deficiencies in serum calcium, elevated serum phosphorus, or increased pressure on the leg veins. Stretching and adjusting the foot position can provide immediate relief from cramps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flex knee and dorsiflex foot: Flexing the knee while dorsiflexing the foot can help in some cases, but extending the knee is generally more effective in relieving cramp pain.

 

Option C. Extend knee and plantar flex foot: Plantar flexion (pointing the toes downward) can actually exacerbate calf cramps. Extending the knee while performing plantar flexion is not as effective for cramp relief.

 

Option D. Flex knee and plantar flex foot: Flexing the knee while performing plantar flexion will likely increase the cramp discomfort. This position may not provide effective relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To relieve leg cramps during pregnancy, extend the knee and dorsiflex the foot.

 

Ref: https://americanpregnancy.org/healthy-pregnancy/pregnancy-health-wellness/leg-cramps-during-pregnancy

choices.text: Apo E1
Apo E2
Apo E3

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apo E4

 

Apolipoprotein E4 is a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD)

 

The chromosome 19 genetic region that codes for apolipoprotein E (ApoE) has a significant impact on the likelihood of developing AD. Based on two amino acid polymorphisms, there are three alleles (alleles 2, 3, and 4). Individuals with the 4 allele are overrepresented in communities of patients with AD because the 4 allele's dosage decreases the age of illness start and raises the risk of AD. According to estimates, this locus accounts for around 25% of the risk for developing sporadic AD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E1: Not commonly recognized in the context of Alzheimer’s risk.

 

Option B. Apo E2: Known to be protective against Alzheimer’s, potentially by promoting a more effective clearance of amyloid-beta from the brain.

 

Option C. Apo E3: The most common allele and considered neutral in terms of Alzheimer’s risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Apo E4 allele is a well-documented genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's disease, influencing the disease's onset and severity. Understanding the genetic risk factors like Apo E4 is crucial for early intervention strategies and for personalizing treatment and management plans for at-risk populations.

 

Apo E2 is protective for Alzheimers disease.

questions.text: Match the following antiarrhythmic drugs with their mechanism of action:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-a, 2-d, 3-b, 4-c

 

The correct match of antiarrhythmic drugs with their mechanisms of action is as follows:

 

  1. Na+ channel blocker (Class Ia):
    • a. Quinidine: Quinidine is a Na+ channel blocker with additional potassium channel blocking properties, classifying it as a Class Ia antiarrhythmic drug. It slows phase 0 of the action potential, leading to a prolonged QRS duration.
  2. K+ channel blocker (Class III):
    • d. Ibutilide: Ibutilide primarily blocks potassium channels, which prolongs repolarization and action potential duration, making it a Class III antiarrhythmic drug.
  3. Na+ K+ ATPase inhibitor:
    • b. Digoxin: Digoxin inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to an increase in intracellular calcium and positive inotropic effects, which is useful in heart failure and some arrhythmias.
  4. Beta-blocker (Class II):
    • c. Esmolol: Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker that reduces heart rate and myocardial contractility by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors, classifying it as a Class II antiarrhythmic drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Quinidine – Na+ Channel Blocker with additional potassium channel blocking property. (class Ia anti-arrhythmic drugs)
  2. Digoxin – Na+-K+-ATPase inhibitor.
  3. Esmolol – β blocker. Belongs to Class II anti arrhythmics.
  4. Ibutilide – K+ channel blocker. Class III anti arrhythmics.

questions.text: Which of the following best represents the primary concern addressed by the POCSO Act? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Child sexual abuse

 

  • The POCSO Act (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012 is designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse and exploitation.
  • It includes provisions for punishment of various offenses such as penetrative sexual assault, aggravated penetrative sexual assault, sexual assault, aggravated sexual assault, sexual harassment, and the use of children for pornography.
  • The act ensures stringent punishment for offenders to provide a safe and secure environment for children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Women empowerment: Incorrect. The POCSO Act is focused on protecting children from sexual offenses, not specifically on women empowerment.

 

Option B. Human trafficking: Incorrect. While important, human trafficking is not the primary focus of the POCSO Act.

 

Option C. Juvenile delinquency: Incorrect. The act deals with protecting children from sexual offenses, not addressing juvenile delinquency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POCSO Act (Prevention of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012

 

  • Child definition: Any person less than 18 years of age
  • Includes: Sexual abuses and pornography
  • Punishments under the act:

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient undergoes an appendicectomy procedure. Two days later, she complains of severe abdominal pain and is found to have a collection of blood in the abdomen on examination. On exploration, it is discovered that a particular artery should have been ligated during the surgery to prevent this complication. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during the appendicectomy procedure to prevent postoperative hemorrhage in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileocolic artery

 

The ileocolic artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) that supplies blood to the appendix and the cecum. During an appendicectomy procedure, it is crucial to identify and ligate the appendicular branch of ileocolic artery to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. Failure to do so can result in bleeding complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right colic artery: The right colic artery is another branch of the SMA that supplies blood to the ascending colon and the right side of the transverse colon. Ligating the right colic artery is not a standard part of an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option C. Superior rectal artery: The superior rectal artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and supplies blood to the rectum. It is not directly related to an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option D. Superior mesenteric artery: The superior mesenteric artery is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to various parts of the small intestine, including the jejunum and ileum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the removal of the appendix, the inferior branch of the ileocolic artery needs to be ligated at the base of the appendix to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. The appendicular artery typically arises directly from the ileocolic artery and supplies the appendix through multiple small branches. If not ligated, the appendicular artery may cause bleeding complications.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presented with gum bleeding, easy bruising, and fatigue. He was suffering from fever for 1 month and on examination, he had pallor and a petechial rash distributed all over the body. His peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and his corrected reticulocyte count was 0.5%. Bone marrow revealed few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells. What should be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic Anemia

 

The patient's presentation of gum bleeding, easy bruising, fatigue, fever, pallor, and petechial rash suggests Pancytopenia. Pancytopenia can result from several conditions, but the key clues here are:

 

  • Bone marrow findings: The bone marrow shows few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells, indicating a hypocellular marrow.
  • Corrected reticulocyte count: A low corrected reticulocyte count (0.5%) indicates poor bone marrow response.

 

These findings are characteristic of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia, a condition where the bone marrow fails to produce adequate amounts of blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disseminated TB: Disseminated TB usually presents with systemic symptoms and may show a cellular bone marrow due to granulomas and other inflammatory changes, which is not consistent with the findings of a hypocellular marrow.

 

Option C. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH typically presents with hemolytic anemia, thrombosis, and sometimes pancytopenia. However, it usually shows a cellular marrow unless it is associated with aplastic anemia. In exams, PNH is generally considered a cause of cellular marrow.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS usually presents with a hypercellular or normocellular marrow with dysplastic changes. It can cause pancytopenia, but the marrow is typically not hypocellular except in rare cases of hypoplastic MDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia should be considered in patients presenting with pancytopenia, bleeding, bruising, fatigue, and hypocellular bone marrow without significant inflammatory or immature cells. The diagnosis is supported by a low corrected reticulocyte count and clinical findings consistent with bone marrow failure.

questions.text: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. Which of the following structures are involved? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The structure involved in causing lurching gait in the child is gluteus medius (marked as 2). The gluteus medius muscle is critical for stabilizing the pelvis during gait. When functioning normally, it prevents the pelvis from dropping to the opposite side during the swing phase of the walk. If injured or dysfunctional, such as might occur from a traumatic fall, the ability to maintain pelvic stability is compromised, leading to a lurching gait, known clinically as a Trendelenburg gait.

 

 

The structure shown in the image are :

 

1-Gluteus maximus

2-Gluteus medius

3-Piriformis

4-Sciatic nerve

 

Other Options:

 

1. Gluteus Maximus: The largest and most superficial of the gluteal muscles, mainly responsible for extension and lateral rotation of the hip. Its involvement is more related to power movements like climbing or jumping rather than gait stability.

 

3. Piriformis: A small muscle located deep in the buttock, behind the gluteus maximus. It helps with lateral rotation of the hip. Although it is near the sciatic nerve, it is less likely involved in producing a lurching gait unless it compresses the sciatic nerve, causing sciatica.

 

4. Sciatic Nerve: The largest nerve in the body, running from the lower back to the feet. While injury to this nerve can cause pain and weakness in the legs, it typically would not cause a lurching gait unless there is significant associated muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical Insight:

 

Injury to the gluteus medius or the superior gluteal nerve can lead to an inability to properly abduct the hip on the stance side, resulting in a drop of the pelvis on the contralateral side when the affected leg is weight-bearing. This is often demonstrated by a positive Trendelenburg sign and manifests as a compensatory lurch toward the affected side to maintain balance.

 

Additional Information

 

Gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip joint. Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus-

 

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • The actions of these muscles are affected when there is an injury to the superior gluteal nerve, neck of the femur, or loss of normal angulation of the shaft of the femur. This occurs in conditions like paralysis of the glutei, developmental dysplasia of the hip, etc.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb. This leads to a positive Trendelenburg's sign with a characteristic lurching gait - the patient lurches towards the affected side with contralateral pelvis drop.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hemostatic agent? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Boric acid

 

Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. Boric acid is commonly used as an antiseptic, insecticide, and in various industrial applications, but it does not possess properties that would promote blood coagulation or control bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zeolite and Option D. Kaolin are microporous aluminosilicate minerals with large surface areas, having high hygroscopicity and excellent hemostatic performance. Zeolite absorbs blood and the releases Ca2+ into the blood and to activate the intrinsic path of coagulation cascade.

 

Option B. Chitosan: Chitosan is a biopolymer derived from chitin, which is found in the shells of crustaceans. Chitosan and its derivatives are known to accelerate the hemostasis process by promoting platelet adhesion and activation. This helps in forming a stable clot more quickly, which is particularly useful in controlling external bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. Hemostatic agents like Zeolite, Chitosan, and Kaolin work by activating the coagulation pathways to control bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following will halter the maturity of collagen?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

Option B. Scurvy:

  • Scurvy is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid).
  • Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen. Without adequate vitamin C, collagen production is impaired, leading to the characteristic symptoms of scurvy, including impaired wound healing and gum bleeding.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Beri-Beri:

  • Beri-Beri is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • Thiamine deficiency primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option C. Night Blindness:

  • Night blindness is often associated with a deficiency in vitamin A (retinol).
  • Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option D. Rickets:

  • Rickets is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.
  • Vitamin D plays a role in calcium and phosphate homeostasis, which is crucial for bone health but does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scurvy is the condition that will halt the maturity of collagen because it is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is essential for collagen synthesis.

 

Ascorbic acid is necessary for the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues.

 

 

Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are essential for the formation of cross links in the collagen, which gives the tensile strength to the fibers. This process is absolutely necessary for the normal production of supporting tissues such as osteoid, collagen and intercellular cement substance of capillaries.

 

Thus, in ascorbic acid deficiency (Scurvy), collagen is abnormal and the intercellular cement substance is brittle. So, capillaries are fragile, leading to the tendency to bleed even under minor pressure.

questions.text: Match the correct parasite with its appropriate intermediate host.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Paragonimus - Crayfish

 

 

Explanation:

 

Paragonimus westermani, commonly known as the lung fluke, uses crayfish and crabs as its second intermediate host. The life cycle begins with the fluke's larvae developing in snails, the first intermediate host. Once the snails release the larvae, they infect crayfish or crabs, which are then consumed by the definitive host (humans), leading to infection. This specific host relationship is crucial for the parasite’s transmission and development.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphyllobothrium - Sheep: Diphyllobothrium latum, the fish tapeworm, does not involve sheep in its life cycle. It utilizes Cyclops as the first intermediate host and fish as the second intermediate host before infecting humans, the definitive host.

 

Option C. Brugia - Cyclops: Brugia malayi, responsible for lymphatic filariasis, uses Mansonia mosquitoes as its intermediate host, not Cyclops. Cyclops is associated with the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium, not Brugia.

 

Option D. Fasciola - Mansonia: Fasciola hepatica, the liver fluke, involves snails as the first intermediate host and aquatic vegetation as the second, eventually infecting sheep or humans. Mansonia mosquitoes are not part of Fasciola’s life cycle.

 

Educational Objective:
