Paragonimus westermani uses crayfish or crabs as its second intermediate host, a key aspect of its life cycle leading to human infection. Understanding the specific host relationships of parasites is essential for diagnosing and preventing infections, particularly in regions where these hosts are commonly consumed.

choices.text: Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
Need antigen processing and presentation for it recognition

questions.text: Which of the following about γδ T-cells is incorrect? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Need antigen processing and presentation for it recognition

 

γδ T-cells do not need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition.

 

There are two types of T cells: γδ T-cells and αβ T-cells.

 

  • The functions of γδ T-cells:
    • Provide protection against mycobacteria by direct killing of infected macrophages
    • Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
    • Plays a role in maintaining self-tolerance
    • Capable of recognizing and lying diverse cancers in an MHC-unrestricted manner
  • The αβ TCR recognizes peptide antigens that are displayed by major histocompatibility complex (MHC. molecules on the surfaces of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). By limiting the specificity of T cells for peptides displayed by cell surface MHC molecules, called MHC restriction, the immune system ensures that T cells see only cell-associated antigens (e.g., those derived from microbes in cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin: This is correct and one of the key functions of γδ T-cells.

 

Option C. Direct killing of infected macrophages: This is correct, as γδ T-cells can directly target and kill infected cells.

 

Option D. Provide protection against mycobacteria: This is correct; γδ T-cells play an important role in defense against mycobacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

γδ T-cells do not require antigen processing and presentation by MHC molecules for their recognition, unlike αβ T-cells, making them unique in their ability to directly recognize and respond to a variety of antigens.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 352-353

choices.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

 

In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pylorus muscle lead to gastric outlet obstruction. This causes projectile, non-bilious vomiting because the obstruction is proximal to the bile duct entry into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visible peristalsis from left to right: Due to the obstruction caused by CHPS, there's an increase in gastric peristalsis as the stomach tries to push its contents past the hypertrophied pylorus. This can result in visible waves of peristalsis moving from the left side of the abdomen (where the stomach is located) to the right side (towards the pylorus) on giving a feed.

 

Option C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia: Persistent vomiting in CHPS can lead to the loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid). This results in hypochloremia due to the loss of chloride ions. The body also tries to compensate for the alkalosis by excreting more potassium in the kidneys, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: As mentioned earlier, the loss of gastric acid from repeated vomiting results in a state of metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

choices.text: Lead poisoning
Iron deficiency anemia
Hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hyper-segmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic alcoholism

 

The given findings are suggestive of macrocytic anemia, which can be seen in chronic alcoholics.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Chronic alcoholics also have deficiency of folic acid due to:

 

  • Folate accumulation in the liver
  • Excessive urinary loss
  • Impaired folate metabolism
  • Chronic alcoholics frequently have insufficient dietary intake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead poisoning: Lead poisoning typically causes microcytic anemia rather than macrocytic anemia. Peripheral smear findings in lead poisoning include basophilic stippling of RBCs, not macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, which contrasts with the macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia generally presents with normocytic or slightly macrocytic RBCs, but not to the extent seen in megaloblastic anemia. Additionally, hyper-segmented neutrophils are not a typical feature of hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrocytic anemia with hyper-segmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear is characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, often due to folate deficiency, which is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to impaired folate metabolism and poor dietary intake.

choices.text: Commonly presents as an abdominal mass
Presents in children < 6 years of age
Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Wilms’ tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

 

Wilms’ tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children, typically under the age of six. It is one of the most common pediatric solid tumors and presents with a variety of clinical features, most notably an abdominal mass.

 

  • Common Presentation: The most common presenting symptom of Wilms’ tumor is a painless abdominal mass, which may be noticed by the child's parents or during a routine physical examination. This aligns with option A, making it correct.
  • Age of Onset: Wilms’ tumor most frequently occurs in young children, particularly those under the age of six. This is well-documented in clinical practice and research, making option B correct.
  • Treatment and Prognosis: The treatment for Wilms’ tumor typically includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiotherapy. The majority of patients have a good prognosis and can recover with appropriate treatment, supporting option C as correct.
  • Lung Metastasis: Contrary to option D, lung metastasis is actually relatively common in Wilms’ tumor and often one of the first sites of metastasis. It is not rare, nor is it necessarily a late feature. Early detection and treatment of lung metastases are crucial in the management of Wilms' tumor, making this option incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Commonly presents as an abdominal mass: This is a correct statement. Wilms’ tumor typically presents as an abdominal mass, which is often the first sign that prompts further investigation.

 

Option B. Presents in children < 6 years of age: This is also correct. The majority of cases occur in children under the age of six, making this a well-recognized feature of the disease.

 

Option C. Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy: This statement is accurate as well. Advances in chemotherapy and radiotherapy have significantly improved survival rates for patients with Wilms’ tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung metastasis in Wilms’ tumor is not rare; it is actually a common site of metastasis and often occurs early in the disease course.

questions.text: Identify the type of ANA staining pattern shown in the image below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Centromeric

 

The given picture shows discrete and large speckles in the resting cells, and the alignment of the speckles in the chromosome region in the dividing cells. This is suggestive of centromeric pattern of ANA staining. Centromeric pattern is seen in limited cutaneous sclerosis (CREST syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogenous: The homogenous pattern is characterized by uniform staining of the entire nucleus. It is commonly associated with antibodies against DNA-histone complexes and is seen in conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

 

Option C. Nucleolar: The nucleolar pattern shows staining of the nucleoli within the nucleus. This pattern is typically seen with anti-nucleolar antibodies, which are often associated with systemic sclerosis, particularly the diffuse form.

 

Option D. Speckled: The speckled pattern features fine or coarse speckles distributed throughout the nucleus but sparing the nucleoli. This pattern is associated with a wide range of autoimmune diseases, including SLE, Sjögren's syndrome, and mixed connective tissue disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The centromeric ANA staining pattern is associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome) and is characterized by discrete speckles aligned with chromosomes in dividing cells.

choices.text: Yolk sac tumor
Granulosa cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following tumors shows the following finding? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Yolk sac tumor

 

The image shows the characteristic Schiller Duval body which is consistent with yolk sac tumor.

 

  • Endodermal sinus tumor or yolk sac tumor is the second most common germ cell tumor
  • Frequently seen in children and young women.
  • The tumor is usually unilateral but may metastasise to the other ovary.
  • It is a highly aggressive and rapidly growing tumor.
  • Grossly, the tumor is nonencapsulated, and on cross-section shows homogeneous, yellow-white, mucinous appearance.
  • Characteristic on microscopic examination
    • Lacelike (reticular) network of medium-sized cuboidal or flattened cells.
    • Papillary structures, solid cords of cells, and a multitude of other less common patterns may be found.
    • Schiller-Duval bodies may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli.
    • Present within and outside the cytoplasm are eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules in which α- fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin can be demonstrated by immunocytochemical staining.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminoma (counterpart of seminoma) is a germ cell tumor. Sheets or cords of large clear cells are seen.

 

Option C. Krukenberg tumor: Krukenberg tumor is a secondary ovarian tumor. Characterized by signet ring” mucin-secreting cells.

 

 

Option D. Granulosa cell tumor: Granulosa cell tumor is Composed of mixture of cuboidal granulosa cells and spindled or plump lipid-laden theca cells. Call-Exner bodies are seen.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Schiller-Duval bodies is a key diagnostic feature of yolk sac tumors, distinguishing them from other types of ovarian tumors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old software engineer presented with fatigue and lethargy. He worked for 12-14 hours a day, and his diet pattern consisted predominantly of fast food with very little veggies and greens. Labs: Hb - 9, MCV 106. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

 

The patient presents with macrocytic anemia, indicated by an MCV of 106. Macrocytic anemia is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. The patient's dietary habits, which include a diet predominantly of fast food with very little vegetables and greens, suggest a lack of dietary folate.

 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Typically occurs in individuals who do not consume animal products (vegans). This deficiency is less likely in this patient due to the absence of such a dietary restriction.
  • Folate deficiency: Common in individuals with poor intake of vegetables and greens. This matches the patient's dietary pattern.
  • Iron deficiency: Results in microcytic anemia (MCV < 80), not macrocytic anemia.
  • Hemolytic anemia: Usually presents as normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100) with increased reticulocyte count and elevated LDH, which does not match the lab findings of this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12 deficiency: While B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, it is more common in individuals who avoid animal products. The patient's history does not indicate a dietary restriction on animal products.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), which is not consistent with the patient's lab findings of an MCV of 106.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia typically presents with normocytic anemia and increased reticulocyte count, not with the high MCV seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency should be considered in patients with macrocytic anemia and poor dietary intake of vegetables and greens. This deficiency can cause fatigue and lethargy and is confirmed by a high MCV and dietary history.

questions.text: Leading questions are permitted during which kind of examination in court? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cross examination 

 

  • Leading questions in law are questions asked by an attorney, to a witness, with the goal of "putting words in the mouth of the witness," to achieve a desired response or result.
  • Answer to leading question can be given in “yes” or “No”
  • Example:
    • Has Ram killed shyam? It is a leading question.
    • Who has killed shyam? It is not a leading question
  • IEA related to leading questions are 141, 142 and 143 IEA (Indian Evidence Act).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Examination-in-chief: Leading questions are generally not allowed during examination-in-chief to prevent the lawyer from influencing the witness's testimony.

 

Option B. Direct examination: Similar to examination-in-chief, direct examination aims to elicit the witness's own account without leading questions.

 

Option D. Re-direct examination: Leading questions are also not allowed in re-direct examination, as the purpose is to clarify or rebut points raised during cross-examination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Leading Questions are Not permitted in: 

  1. Examination in chief
  2. Re-Examination
  3. Dying Declaration

 

Leading Questions are permitted in: 

  1. Cross Examination
  2. Dying Deposition
  3. Hostile witness is an exception wherein the leading questions can be asked even in examination in chief

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical mupirocin

 

Topical mupirocin is the preferred agent for the elimination of nasal carriers of MRSA.

 

Decolonization therapy is the administration of antimicrobial or antiseptic agents to eradicate or suppress MRSA carriage:

 

  • Intranasal antibiotic or antiseptic (e.g., mupirocin, povidone-iodine)
  • Topical antiseptic (e.g., chlorhexidine)
  • +/- Systemic antibiotics

 

MRSA decolonization has been associated with reduction in MRSA carriage, transmission and infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral vancomycin: While effective against MRSA, oral vancomycin is not used for nasal decolonization. It is primarily used for treating severe systemic MRSA infections and Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea.

 

Option B. Inj cephalosporin: Cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics that are generally ineffective against MRSA due to resistance mechanisms. They are not used for MRSA nasal decolonization.

 

Option D. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is an antibiotic used for treating multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections, particularly in the lungs. It is not used for nasal decolonization of MRSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical mupirocin is the recommended treatment for the nasal decolonization of MRSA, effectively reducing the nasal carriage of the bacteria and thereby decreasing the risk of transmission and subsequent infections.

questions.text: The below-given image is characteristically seen in which of the following type of leprosy? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Borderline leprosy (BB Leprosy)

 

The given image shows a case of borderline leprosy, or dimorphous leprosy, as evidenced by the inverted saucer shaped cutaneous lesions on the patient's skin.

 

Key Characteristics of Borderline Leprosy

 

  • Lesions: Borderline leprosy often presents with numerous skin lesions which may be macular (flat), papular (raised), or annular (ring-shaped) with less defined borders compared to tuberculoid leprosy. The lesions can sometimes exhibit an "inverted saucer" appearance, where the center appears slightly depressed.
  • Symmetry: The lesions tend to be asymmetrical.
  • Sensory Loss: These lesions usually show some sensory loss, although not as pronounced as in tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Reactivity: Borderline leprosy is particularly unstable immunologically, prone to reactivations and shifts toward either more or less severe forms, depending on immune changes in the individual.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Borderline Tuberculoid Leprosy: Closer to the tuberculoid pole with fewer, well-defined lesions and significant nerve involvement.

 

Option B. Lepromatous Leprosy: At the opposite pole from tuberculoid leprosy, characterized by numerous lesions including nodules and plaques, with a high bacterial load but minimal sensory loss.

 

Option D. Histoid Leprosy: A rare variant of lepromatous leprosy presenting as nodules and plaques, often occurring in patients who have experienced leprosy treatment or relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with borderline leprosy are at risk for developing reactions like Type 1 (reversal) reactions, which can lead to rapid worsening of lesions and require immediate medical attention.
  • Accurate diagnosis based on clinical presentation, bacterial index, and histopathology is crucial as the treatment duration and regimen may differ based on the type of leprosy. Borderline leprosy is typically treated with multi-drug therapy (MDT), similar to other forms of leprosy.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9th edition page no 28.3, 28.5, 28.10

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic cough, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss presents to the clinic. He reports that his symptoms have been worsening over the past few months, and he recently noticed blood-tinged sputum. A chest X-ray shows cavitary lesions in the upper lobes, and a sputum sample is sent for analysis. The slide from the sputum sample is shown below. Which organism is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario and imaging findings are highly suggestive of tuberculosis, which is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The organism is identified by its acid-fast characteristics, which are visualized using Ziehl-Neelsen stain. This stain shows Mycobacterium tuberculosis as pink, non-branching bacilli on a blue background due to the high lipid content in its cell wall, primarily mycolic acid. The clinical symptoms of chronic cough, night sweats, and cavitary lesions on imaging further support this diagnosis, which is commonly seen in patients with exposure to endemic areas or risk factors for tuberculosis.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Nocardia: Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filamentous organisms, not the non-branching bacilli seen in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It typically presents in immunocompromised patients and is associated with pulmonary infections resembling tuberculosis but has distinct morphological characteristics.

 

Option C. Actinomyces: Actinomyces species are not acid-fast and do not appear on Ziehl-Neelsen staining as pink bacilli. They present as gram-positive, branching filaments and are usually involved in infections of the cervicofacial region, chest, or abdomen, unrelated to the symptoms seen here.

 

Option D. Corynebacterium: Corynebacterium species are gram-positive rods that are non-acid-fast and do not stain with Ziehl-Neelsen stain. They do not appear as pink, non-branching bacilli and are more commonly associated with diphtheria rather than chronic respiratory conditions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a leading cause of chronic pulmonary infections characterized by cavitary lesions, cough, and constitutional symptoms. It is identified by its acid-fast properties, appearing as pink, non-branching bacilli on Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to its high mycolic acid content. Recognizing the clinical presentation and specific staining characteristics is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management of tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following protein deficiency is responsible for Hereditary Angioedema? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C1 inhibitor  

 

Hereditary angioedema (HAE) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). The condition is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the C1 inhibitor protein. C1 inhibitor is crucial in regulating the complement system, particularly the classical pathway, by inhibiting the activity of C1 esterase. In the absence or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor, uncontrolled activation of the complement pathway occurs, leading to excessive production of bradykinin, a potent vasodilator that causes the symptoms of angioedema.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decay accelerating factor: Also known as CD55, this protein is responsible for regulating the complement system on cell surfaces, preventing damage to host cells. Deficiency of CD55 is associated with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), not hereditary angioedema.

 

Option C. CD59: This protein is also involved in the regulation of the complement system by inhibiting the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Like CD55, CD59 deficiency is associated with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), not hereditary angioedema.

 

Option D. C5 convertase: This is an enzyme complex that plays a role in the complement cascade by cleaving C5 into C5a and C5b, leading to the formation of the membrane attack complex. Deficiencies in components of C5 convertase can lead to increased susceptibility to infections, particularly with Neisseria species, but it is not associated with hereditary angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

 

  • In the given scenario of dilated pancreatic duct with stones, a drainage procedure in the form of longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy (Peusthow) is preferred.
  • CHRONIC PANCREATITIS - Irreversible damage to architecture of pancreas.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple’s procedure): This procedure involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and bile duct. It is typically reserved for malignancies or specific inflammatory conditions localized to the head of the pancreas. It is not the primary choice for diffuse chronic pancreatitis with a dilated duct.

 

Option C. ERCP and sphincterotomy: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy can aid in the removal of pancreatic calculi but is not considered a long-term solution for chronic pancreatitis with a significantly dilated duct.

 

Option D. Coring of the pancreas head: Coring of the pancreatic head may be considered if inflammation is limited to the head of the pancreas alone, but it is not suitable for the diffuse dilation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with chronic pancreatitis and a significantly dilated pancreatic duct (greater than 6 mm), the preferred surgical treatment is longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (Peustow procedure).
  • This procedure helps to relieve ductal hypertension and improve drainage, alleviating pain and other symptoms associated with chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is referred to a neurologist with complaints of facial flushing and sweating while eating or even just thinking about food. The patient reports that this has been happening for several months and is becoming increasingly bothersome. Upon further questioning, the patient also reports a history of parotid gland surgery for a benign tumor several years ago. Which nerve is involved in Frey's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Frey's syndrome is a rare condition that occurs as a complication of parotid gland surgery or other trauma to the area. It is characterized by facial flushing and sweating in the region of the face associated with the parotid gland, particularly when eating or thinking about food. The underlying cause of Frey's syndrome is damage to the auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, V3). This damage results in abnormal nerve regeneration and cross-connection between the parasympathetic fibers that stimulate salivation and the sympathetic fibers that control sweating.

 

  • Mechanism: The auriculotemporal nerve contains both sensory fibers and parasympathetic secretomotor fibers that supply the parotid gland. Following injury or surgery, these fibers can aberrantly regenerate, causing parasympathetic fibers to innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin, leading to sweating and flushing upon salivation.

 

Treatment Options:

 

  • Topical Antiperspirants: These can help reduce sweating by blocking sweat glands.
  • Oral Medications: Medications that reduce sweating may be prescribed.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injections: These injections can block the action of sweat glands, providing relief from symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve controls facial expressions and can be injured during parotid surgery, leading to facial palsy. However, it is not involved in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve controls eye movements and pupil constriction and is not involved in the innervation of the parotid gland or the region affected in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is involved in taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue and parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland. However, it is not directly involved in the facial flushing and sweating characteristic of Frey's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey's syndrome is caused by damage to the auriculotemporal nerve, leading to abnormal sweating and flushing of the face associated with eating or thinking about food. This condition is a common complication of parotid gland surgery.

choices.text: Inhibition of acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction
Inhibition of presynaptic GABA and glycine release
Blockage of sodium channels on motor neurons
Enhancement of acetylcholine degradation

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with generalized muscle spasms, difficulty opening his mouth, and arching of his back. He sustained a puncture wound to his leg from a rusty nail about a week ago and did not seek medical attention until now. His examination reveals trismus, risus sardonicus, and opisthotonos. Based on the clinical presentation and the images provided, which mechanism of action is responsible for the toxin causing this abnormal posturing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Inhibition of presynaptic GABA and glycine release

 

Explanation:

 

Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani, an obligate anaerobic, gram-positive bacillus that produces tetanospasmin, a neurotoxin responsible for the clinical manifestations of tetanus. The toxin inhibits the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine from presynaptic terminals in the central nervous system. The toxin binds to motor neuron terminals and is transported retrogradely to the central nervous system, where it blocks inhibitory signals, leading to unopposed excitatory transmission and continuous muscle contraction.

 

Mechanism of Tetanus Toxin: Tetanospasmin binds to polysialogangliosides receptors on motor nerve terminals, leading to internalization and retrograde axonal transport to the central nervous system. Once at the inhibitory neuron terminals, the toxin prevents the presynaptic release of GABA and glycine, resulting in disinhibition of motor neurons and continuous stimulation of muscles.

 

Clinical Features: Patients typically present with muscle rigidity and painful spasms, including trismus (lockjaw), risus sardonicus (sardonic grin due to facial muscle spasm), and opisthotonos (severe back arching). Spasms can be triggered by minor stimuli such as noise or touch. Autonomic dysfunction may also occur, leading to fluctuations in heart rate and blood pressure.

 

Incubation Period: The incubation period of tetanus is typically 6-10 days, but this can vary depending on the location and nature of the wound.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Inhibition of acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction: This mechanism is characteristic of botulism caused by Clostridium botulinum. Botulinum toxin blocks acetylcholine release, leading to flaccid paralysis rather than the spastic paralysis seen in tetanus.

 

Option C. Blockage of sodium channels on motor neurons: This mechanism is associated with local anesthetics or certain neurotoxins but is not responsible for the pathophysiology of tetanus. Blocking sodium channels would inhibit nerve conduction, resulting in numbness or paralysis rather than muscle spasms.

 

Option D. Enhancement of acetylcholine degradation: Acetylcholine degradation is primarily regulated by acetylcholinesterase. Enhancement of this process would decrease acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness rather than the spasticity seen in tetanus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani, which produces tetanospasmin, a neurotoxin that inhibits the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to continuous muscle contractions and spasms. The clinical features include trismus, risus sardonicus, and opisthotonos, and the disease typically has an incubation period of 6-10 days. Recognizing these symptoms is crucial for early diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A pituitary tumor that overproduced growth hormone was surgically removed from a patient. The resection was discovered to be insufficient. What is the patient's first-line treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Octreotide

 

Octreotide is a synthetic somatostatin analog that inhibits the secretion of growth hormone (GH) from the pituitary gland. It is the first-line treatment for patients with acromegaly when surgery alone is insufficient to control GH levels. Octreotide binds to somatostatin receptors, reducing GH production and controlling symptoms of acromegaly.

 


Other Options:

 

Option A. Leuprolide: Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist primarily used in the treatment of hormone-sensitive cancers such as prostate cancer, and conditions like endometriosis and uterine fibroids. It is not used for reducing GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Option B. Goserelin: Goserelin is another GnRH agonist used for similar indications as leuprolide, including prostate cancer and breast cancer, as well as for managing endometriosis. It is not indicated for GH reduction in acromegaly.

 

Option C. Nafarelin: Nafarelin also a GnRH agonist, is used for the treatment of endometriosis and central precocious puberty. Like the other GnRH agonists, it is not used to manage GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Octreotide is used for the treatment of the following conditions: (SOMATostatin)

 

S: Secretory diarrhea due to carcinoid tumor, VIPomas, following cancer chemotherapy, AIDS etc.

 

O: Oesophageal varices (Acute Variceal bleeding)

 

M: Malignancy like Insulinoma and Glucagonoma

 

A: Acromegaly due to GH secreting pituitary adenoma

 

T: Thyrotrope adenoma

 

  • Leuprolide, Goeserelin and Nafarelin are GnRH agonists.

questions.text: A person arrived with a lesion on their left buttock. This individual has a past medical record of undergoing a heart transplant 15 years ago. Analysis of the fluid extracted from the lesion reveals the presence of gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the probable microbial agent responsible for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The provided clinical situation involving a localized abscess and an aspirate displaying filamentous gram-positive bacteria indicates a likelihood of Nocardia infection.

 

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive branching filamentous bacilli.

 

 

  • Modified acid-fast staining: using 1% sulfuric acid as decolorizer (Kinyoun method): Nocardiae are partially acid-fast and appear as branching and filamentous red colored acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

  • Histopathology (H and E stain) of the granules: Shows multilobulated with sun-ray appearance.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Bacillus anthracis, on culture, are arranged end-to-end in long chains → Bamboo-stick appearance.

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae is an acid-fast, Gram-positive, rod shaped bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite.

 

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis appear weakly Gram-positive. Acid fast stain is used to identify it.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacillus, particularly seen in immunocompromised patients, and can be identified using modified acid-fast staining.
